reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s antirealist/subjectivist discussion (2.4.2) and, more broadly, the essay’s practical/normative upshot—so it is somewhat central, but it doesn’t directly engage the essay’s main claims about convergence/trade/threats under moral uncertainty. Its main move is meta-level: if subjectivism is true, then talk of ‘mostly-great’ lacks objective normative authority, so the essay can’t demand assent. That’s partly right (subjectivism undermines objective, stance-independent ‘better’), but it overreaches: subjectivism doesn’t ‘defeat caring’ or decision-relevance; it just relocates reasons to agents’/readers’ preferences (or to moral uncertainty across non-subjectivist views), which the essay explicitly leans on. So it modestly pressures the rhetoric/ambition of the subjectivist argument, but doesn’t substantially refute the core position. It’s clearly stated, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Subjectivism undermines both convergence and the paper's own normative stakes
